quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Most productivity metrics are a lie. If the goal is more lines of code, I can prompt something to write the longest piece of code ever. It's just too easy to gain that system.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: A contrarian warning that common output metrics (like LOC) become meaningless—and easily gamed—especially with AI.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Most teams can move faster. But faster for what? We can ship trash faster every single day. We need strategy and really smart decisions to know what to ship.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: Reframes “speed” as a strategy problem, pushing teams to optimize for outcomes and decision quality, not just throughput.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We can't just put in a command and guess something back and accept it. We really need to evaluate it. Are we seeing hallucinations? What's the reliability? Does it meet the style that we would typically write?
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: Actionable checklist for AI-generated code review: validate correctness, reliability, and alignment with team standards.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: There's some real opportunity there to not just rethink workflows, but rethink how we structure our days and how we structure our work. Now, we can also make a 45-minute work block useful because getting into the flow is actually kind of handed off, at least, in part to the machine or the machine can help us get back into the flow by, reminding us of context and generating diagrams of the system.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: A practical mental model for AI-era productivity: redesign work around shorter focus blocks and use AI to restore context and flow.

quotes.topic_title: DevEx definition and why it matters
quotes.text: DevEx is developer experience. And when we think about developer experience, we're really talking about what it's like to build software, day to day, for a developer. So the friction that they face, the workflows that they have to go through, any support that they have.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: A practical definition of DevEx that breaks it into observable levers teams can measure and improve (friction, workflows, support).

quotes.topic_title: DevEx definition and why it matters
quotes.text: It's important because when DevEx is poor, everything else just isn't going to help. The best processes, the best tools, the best... whatever magic you have, if the DevEx is bad, everything kind of takes-
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: A prioritization rule: fixing DevEx is a prerequisite for tools/process improvements to pay off.

quotes.topic_title: DevEx definition and why it matters
quotes.text: But if you're getting there in ways that are high toil or high friction, then at some point, a developer is going to burn out.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: A warning that output-only productivity can be misleading if it’s achieved via unsustainable toil and friction.

quotes.topic_title: DevEx definition and why it matters
quotes.text: Or if it's super high cognitive load, if it's hard to even think about what you're doing because concentrating on the mechanics of... the plumbing of something, then you don't have the brain space left to come up with really innovative solutions and questions.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: A mental model linking cognitive load to innovation capacity—reduce “plumbing” overhead to unlock better problem-solving.

quotes.topic_title: DevEx definition and why it matters
quotes.text: So I love that it's kind of this self-reinforcing loop in terms of, "You do more work, you do better work." And it's better for people, it's better for the systems, it's better for our customers.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: Frames DevEx improvements as a virtuous cycle that compounds across people, systems, and customer outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Flow state, cognitive load, and AI’s impact
quotes.text: Well, there are lots of different ways to talk about DevEx. One way to talk about it is kind of three key things that have components that are important of themselves, and they also kind of reinforce each other. Flow state is one of them, cognitive load is another, and then feedback loops are another.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: Introduces a practical 3-part DevEx framework (flow, cognitive load, feedback loops) that teams can use to evaluate AI tooling impact beyond raw output.

quotes.topic_title: Flow state, cognitive load, and AI’s impact
quotes.text: Instead, you're kind of creating a prompt, getting some code back and reviewing the code, trying to integrate what's happening in the system, and that can really interrupt.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: Highlights a concrete mechanism by which AI can harm productivity—prompt/review/integration cycles that fragment attention and break flow.

quotes.topic_title: Flow state, cognitive load, and AI’s impact
quotes.text: I've seen some senior engineers pull together some tool chains that are really incredible, where they figured out how to keep the flow going. The fast feedback loops really, really work well for them.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: Points to an actionable lever—investing in toolchains and faster feedback loops—to preserve flow even with AI in the loop.

quotes.topic_title: Flow state, cognitive load, and AI’s impact
quotes.text: Instead of details and line-by-line writing, they're in the flow in terms of, "What's my goal? What are the pieces that I need to get there? How quickly can I get there? So then, I can step back and kind of evaluate everything, and then dive back in and fix some pieces."
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: Offers a memorable mental model shift: flow moves from typing code to goal-setting, decomposition, rapid iteration, and evaluation.

quotes.topic_title: Flow state, cognitive load, and AI’s impact
quotes.text: Because they were so systematic about it upfront, they're much closer to something that looks like production code.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: Gives a specific, counterintuitive practice: more upfront systematization/priming can yield higher-quality AI output than "vibe coded" iteration.

quotes.topic_title: Why AI breaks traditional productivity metrics
quotes.text: I'll say most productivity metrics are a lie.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: A contrarian reset that warns teams to distrust common productivity dashboards—especially when AI changes what “output” even means.

quotes.topic_title: Why AI breaks traditional productivity metrics
quotes.text: Well, now, for many of the systems, that they would sometimes whisper and not super talk about that uses lines of code, it's just blown out of the water because, "What do you mean by lines of code?"
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: Highlights how AI makes LOC-based measurement ambiguous and invalid, forcing teams to redefine what they’re actually measuring.

quotes.topic_title: Why AI breaks traditional productivity metrics
quotes.text: If the goal is more lines of code, I can prompt something to write the longest piece of code ever and add tons of comments.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: A concrete example of how AI makes traditional metrics trivially gameable and can incentivize bloat.

quotes.topic_title: Why AI breaks traditional productivity metrics
quotes.text: But now, it's kind of more relevant if we can tease out which code came from people and which code came from AI because now we can answer downstream questions.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: Introduces a practical measurement shift: track provenance so you can evaluate downstream outcomes rather than raw output.

quotes.topic_title: Why AI breaks traditional productivity metrics
quotes.text: "What is the code survivability rate? What is the quality of our code? Is our code being fed back into trained systems? And for that code that's retraining systems later, especially if we're doing fine-tuning and local tuning, how much of that is machine generated? What types of loops is that creating, and what types of patterns or biases might it be inadvertently introducing?"
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: A novel framework for AI-era productivity: measure survivability, quality, and retraining feedback loops (including bias risks) instead of just speed/volume.

quotes.topic_title: DORA vs SPACE in an AI world
quotes.text: I will say if it is a prescriptive metric, it needs to be used only in the way it was prescribed.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: A cautionary rule-of-thumb: prescriptive metrics break when repurposed beyond their intended scope, especially in AI-assisted development.

quotes.topic_title: DORA vs SPACE in an AI world
quotes.text: If those are used to assess the speed of the pipeline and the general performance of the pipeline, that's great.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: Clarifies the “fit for purpose” use-case for DORA: measuring pipeline speed and stability rather than broad productivity.

quotes.topic_title: DORA vs SPACE in an AI world
quotes.text: So I'll say, sometimes people get real frustrated because I didn't tell them what to measure. But now, I think that's the power of it.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: A counterintuitive argument for flexible measurement frameworks (SPACE) over fixed metric sets in fast-changing contexts like AI.

quotes.topic_title: DORA vs SPACE in an AI world
quotes.text: "What proportion of work is being offloaded to a chat bot versus talking to a senior engineer on the team?" More isn't always better and less isn't always better, it depends.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: Offers a concrete, measurable example for collaboration/communication in AI-era teams—and warns against simplistic optimization.

quotes.topic_title: DORA vs SPACE in an AI world
quotes.text: LLMs are non-deterministic.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: A foundational mental model that motivates adding trust/reliability as a first-class dimension in AI productivity measurement.

quotes.topic_title: Trust, code review, and rethinking work structure
quotes.text: I think it'll be interesting to see how that impacts the way we structure work moving forward.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: Frames AI’s impact as a catalyst to redesign work structure, not just speed up coding.

quotes.topic_title: Trust, code review, and rethinking work structure
quotes.text: We were talking about flow state and cognitive load. Now that our attention has to focus on things at certain times and it's broken up from how we used to do it, I think there's some real opportunity there to, not just rethink workflows, but rethink how we structure our days and how we structure our work.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: A mental model for treating attention fragmentation as a design constraint—and an opportunity—for team operating systems.

quotes.topic_title: Trust, code review, and rethinking work structure
quotes.text: Gloria Mark has done some really good work on attention and deep work, and humans can get about four hours of good deep work a day. That's about it.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: A concrete benchmark teams can use when planning schedules, meetings, and expectations for “deep work.”

quotes.topic_title: Trust, code review, and rethinking work structure
quotes.text: But does that mean that now we can also make a 45-minute work block useful? Because getting into the flow is actually kind of handed off, at least, in part to the machine or the machine can help us get back into the flow by reminding us of context and generating diagrams of the system and all the things.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: Counterintuitive idea: AI can reduce the “re-entry cost” of interruptions, making shorter focus blocks productive if tools restore context fast.

quotes.topic_title: Business case for DevEx and quick starting advice
quotes.text: And I think DevEx is important because it enables all of that software creation, it enables all of that problem solving. It enables the super rapid experimentation with customers that... Before, you'd need a while for a prototype and maybe a little bit longer to actually flight it through an A/B test on a production system. You can do it in hours, right now.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: Connects DevEx directly to faster customer experimentation and business outcomes, not just “engineers doing more.”

quotes.topic_title: Business case for DevEx and quick starting advice
quotes.text: Honestly, I think the best thing you can do is go talk to people and listen.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: A simple, immediately actionable starting point for improving DevEx before investing in solutions.

quotes.topic_title: Business case for DevEx and quick starting advice
quotes.text: And I would say start with listening and not with tools and automation.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: Counterintuitive guidance that challenges the default “build tooling” instinct when tackling developer experience.

quotes.topic_title: Business case for DevEx and quick starting advice
quotes.text: If you just go talk to people and ask the developers like, "Think of yesterday, what did you do yesterday? Walk me through it. What were the points that were just delightful? What were the points that were really difficult? Where did you get frustrated? Where did you get slowed down? Where was there friction?"
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: Provides a concrete interview script practitioners can use to surface high-impact DevEx issues quickly.

quotes.topic_title: Business case for DevEx and quick starting advice
quotes.text: Sometimes all you have to do is change a process.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: Highlights that major DevEx wins can come from lightweight process fixes rather than big platform rewrites.

quotes.topic_title: Common DevEx improvements: process, comms, and support
quotes.text: I'll say, I'll kind of echo that process, there's almost always a process that can be improved and that can be improved without a lot of engineering lift or a lot of engineering headcount.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: Highlights a high-leverage starting point for DevEx: simplify process before investing in more tools or staffing.

quotes.topic_title: Common DevEx improvements: process, comms, and support
quotes.text: Most large companies, in particular, have something that is several, several steps. It's the way it is because it's the way it is, but that's no longer the way it is.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: A memorable prompt to challenge inherited bureaucracy and remove unnecessary steps that slow delivery.

quotes.topic_title: Common DevEx improvements: process, comms, and support
quotes.text: So if you can create a very lightweight process, that can also be helpful. That can be one of the best places to start, especially if you have limited exposure to the whole rest of the org. Sometimes just a team process can help.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: Offers a practical methodology: start locally with lightweight team-level process improvements even without org-wide influence.

quotes.topic_title: Common DevEx improvements: process, comms, and support
quotes.text: Communicate what you're doing, communicate what the priorities are, communicate why this is important, to celebrate wins.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: Actionable leadership checklist for sustaining DevEx change through clarity, alignment, and reinforcement.

quotes.topic_title: Common DevEx improvements: process, comms, and support
quotes.text: There are a lot of technical pieces that are involved, but that's not the only thing. It's necessary but not sufficient, and that doesn't have to be the place that you start.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: Counterbalances tool-first instincts with a mental model: tech matters, but it’s not enough—and not always the best starting point.

quotes.topic_title: How to tell if engineering should move faster
quotes.text: Most teams can move faster, right? Also, given what we know about cognitive load, not all speed gains are necessarily good. Or the upside is going to be kind of limited once you hit kind of a certain point, and most people are not even near that point.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: Reframes “move faster” as a tradeoff with cognitive load and diminishing returns, helping leaders avoid naive speed-chasing.

quotes.topic_title: How to tell if engineering should move faster
quotes.text: But how do you know? You know if you're always hearing about bills breaking, flaky tests, overly long processes, if you have to request a new system or if you need to provision a new environment, or if it's really, really hard to switch tasks or switch projects.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: Gives a practical diagnostic checklist of “friction smells” that indicate the team could likely move faster with better engineering systems.

quotes.topic_title: How to tell if engineering should move faster
quotes.text: Because once you finally figure out your system and you're able to get work done, the switching costs can often be really, really high to go anywhere else.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: Highlights context-switch costs as a hidden productivity tax and a signal of overly complex or inconsistent internal systems.

quotes.topic_title: How to tell if engineering should move faster
quotes.text: But I've worked with companies where switching orgs within the company, you had to basically pay the same tax as a new hire because the systems were so different and they were so full of friction, and it was so difficult to do so many things.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: A concrete example showing how fragmented tooling/processes can make internal mobility as costly as onboarding, slowing the whole org.

quotes.topic_title: How to tell if engineering should move faster
quotes.text: We can ship trash faster every single day. We need strategy and really smart decisions to know what to ship, what to experiment with, what features we want to do in what order and what rollout. The strategy is the core piece, and then think about speeding that up. If we don't have the other pieces in place, I mean, garbage in, garbage out.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: Warns that speed without strategy just accelerates bad outcomes, and emphasizes sequencing: decide well first, then optimize delivery.

quotes.topic_title: AI accelerates execution; strategy and experimentation matter
quotes.text: I think there are a lot of ways that we can pull in AI tools to help us refine our strategy, refine our message, think about the experimentation methods or targets of experimentation, or think about our total addressable market, but we need to have that strategy and plan fairly well aligned or at least have two or three alternatives that you want to test.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: Emphasizes that AI-driven speed only pays off when teams have clear strategic alignment and explicit alternatives to test.

quotes.topic_title: AI accelerates execution; strategy and experimentation matter
quotes.text: We can throw out prototypes. We can run any tests and experiments that are customer facing, assuming that we have the infrastructure in place, which allows us to learn and progress much faster before.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: Highlights a practical prerequisite (infrastructure) for turning faster prototyping into faster learning cycles.

quotes.topic_title: AI accelerates execution; strategy and experimentation matter
quotes.text: In some places, it used to take months to get something through production to do A/B testing and get feedback. We can do this in a day or two, definitely under a week.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: Provides a concrete before/after benchmark for how AI and modern tooling can compress experimentation timelines.

quotes.topic_title: AI accelerates execution; strategy and experimentation matter
quotes.text: Let's not just YOLO A/B tests because that can be... It's a shame to do a large test and end up disrupting users or disrupting customers, or breaking privacy or security protocols and also end up with data that's unusable because you just can't get the signal that you're looking for.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: Warns that accelerating experimentation without rigor can create user harm and unusable results, undermining the whole point of faster cycles.

quotes.topic_title: AI accelerates execution; strategy and experimentation matter
quotes.text: But now, I'm also seeing people kind of accelerate that into a few days versus a few weeks. So they can start those key stakeholder discussions from a much more informed kind of filled out space.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: Notes a process shift: using AI to get informed faster and improve stakeholder alignment earlier in the cycle.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Imagine starting a project at work and your vision is clear, you know exactly who's what and where to find the data that you need to do your part.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights a practical ideal-state for project setup: clear ownership and instantly discoverable information.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: In fact, you don't have to waste time searching for anything because everything your team needs from project trackers and OKRs, the documents and spreadsheets lives in one tab all in Coda.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Actionable productivity lever: reduce context-switching and search time by consolidating key artifacts in one place.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With Coda's collaborative all-in-one workspace, you get the flexibility of docs, the structure of spreadsheets, the power of applications, and the intelligence of AI all in one easy-to-organize tab.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Memorable “bundle” framing of capabilities that teams typically stitch together across multiple tools.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I personally use Coda every single day to manage my podcast and also to manage my community.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Concrete example of using a single workspace to run two distinct operational workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And more than 50,000 teams trust Coda to keep them more aligned and focused.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Specific adoption data point supporting the claim that the tool is used at scale for alignment and focus.

quotes.topic_title: Observed AI productivity gains and where they show up
quotes.text: I'd say it's real, and I would also say we don't have great measures for it yet. We're still trying to figure out what to measure and what that looks like.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: Sets the expectation that AI productivity gains exist but measurement is still immature, guiding practitioners to be careful about what they optimize for.

quotes.topic_title: Observed AI productivity gains and where they show up
quotes.text: One of the best is going to be velocity, all the way through the system, how quickly can you get a feature or a product or something through the system so that you can then experiment a test, either from idea to final end or even kind of a feature and a piece through the system so we can test.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: Offers an end-to-end throughput/velocity framing for measuring AI impact where it matters: shipping and learning speed.

quotes.topic_title: Observed AI productivity gains and where they show up
quotes.text: they found that AI was generating significantly more code for the people who were using it regularly. But then, they also found that for folks who were regular users of AI coding environments, AI ADEs, the tool kind of gave them more code. And then the engineers themselves, the increase was double what the coding agent had given them.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: Provides a concrete (and surprising) data point that suggests second-order productivity effects beyond what the agent directly outputs.

quotes.topic_title: Observed AI productivity gains and where they show up
quotes.text: So one, I'd say, probably it's kind of a secondary or knock on or just a smell is it can unblock you. It can speed up the work that you would already do.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: Highlights a practical way AI helps day-to-day: reducing friction and accelerating existing workflows rather than replacing them.

quotes.topic_title: Observed AI productivity gains and where they show up
quotes.text: It turns out, agents rely on good data because it's all about how they've been trained or how they've been grounded. And better data gives you better outcomes, and some of that data includes documentation and comments. The better documentation and the better comments you have, the better performance you're going to get out of your AI tools.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: Counteracts the “docs don’t matter with agents” narrative and gives an actionable lever: improve docs/comments to improve AI tool performance.

quotes.topic_title: Frictionless book overview and seven-step process
quotes.text: Go talk to people, have a listening tour, synthesize what you learn, visualize the workflow and tools, get a handle on what the current state is.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: A concrete starting playbook for diagnosing DevEx issues before jumping to solutions.

quotes.topic_title: Frictionless book overview and seven-step process
quotes.text: Step two is to get a quick win. So start small, get a quick win, pick the right projects, share out what you've done.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: Emphasizes building momentum and credibility early through small, visible improvements.

quotes.topic_title: Frictionless book overview and seven-step process
quotes.text: Step five is to sell your strategy. Once you've decided, now you have to kind of convince everyone else. So now you want to get feedback, you want to share why this is the right strategy right now.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: Highlights that DevEx success depends on stakeholder alignment and change leadership, not just technical fixes.

quotes.topic_title: Frictionless book overview and seven-step process
quotes.text: How can we think about developer experience as a product, and how do we think about the metrics that we have as a product?
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for applying product thinking (and product-quality metrics) to internal developer platforms and workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Frictionless book overview and seven-step process
quotes.text: There's so much low-hanging fruit, there's so much unlocked potential, and it's hard to know where to start a lot of times
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that the biggest barrier is often prioritization and sequencing, not lack of smart people or tools.

quotes.topic_title: DevEx teams: staffing, rollout patterns, and impact
quotes.text: If it's only about productivity, then it's just lines of code or number PRs or whatever. But we really want to talk about value and how do we unlock value, and how do we get value faster.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: Reframes DevEx measurement away from output metrics toward value delivery and speed-to-value.

quotes.topic_title: DevEx teams: staffing, rollout patterns, and impact
quotes.text: So if you're doing it yourself, you could do it with a couple of engineers, maybe a PM or a PGM or a TPM to kind of help communicate. Because really, comms plans are just so important here.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: Gives a practical starter team composition and highlights communications as a core success factor.

quotes.topic_title: DevEx teams: staffing, rollout patterns, and impact
quotes.text: On a small scale, what we want to do is look for those quick wins, look for things that you can do at small scale. Some folks call them things like paper cuts.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: Offers a rollout pattern: start with small “paper cut” fixes to build momentum and credibility.

quotes.topic_title: DevEx teams: staffing, rollout patterns, and impact
quotes.text: I'll say I've seen a huge impact for smaller companies, hundreds of thousands of dollars for large companies or in the billions.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: Provides an ROI range that helps justify DevEx investment at different company scales.

quotes.topic_title: DevEx teams: staffing, rollout patterns, and impact
quotes.text: I will mention that it tends to follow something like the J-curve. So you'll have a couple of quick wins and it'll look like a big win, and then you'll hit kind of a little divot where suddenly the really obvious projects, the low-hanging fruit are handled.
quotes.speaker: Nicole Forsgren
quotes.context: Introduces a mental model for expected impact over time, warning teams to plan for a mid-phase dip after early wins.
